title: Walks around Wakefield Walking Route

images.title: Mike Kirby / Lowe Hill, Clarence Park
images.caption: Lowe Hill, Clarence Park. Lowe Hill in Clarence park contains a medieval motte with two baileys to the north east. Excavations in 1953 indicated that the motte is probably an unfinished 12th century adulterine castle.

images.title: RichTea, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: West end of the lake, Holmfield Park

images.title: Mike Kirby / Holmfield House
images.caption: Holmfield House. Another view of this fine building, now a pub/restaurant. Originally the house was called Holme Field, now shortened to Holmfield.

images.title: Mike Kirby / Thornes Park entrance
images.caption: Thornes Park entrance. Two storks originally perched on these pillars, but were taken by thieves. The lodge, now the Stork cafe, is just inside the entrance.

images.title: SMJ / Trees in Clarence Park
images.caption: Trees in Clarence Park. Looking towards Lawefield Lane with the spire of Wakefield Cathedral in the distance.

images.title: RichTea, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Clarence Park and Wakefield City Centre. From Lowe Hill in Clarence Park. The two towers on the left are on West Yorkshire County Hall (short) and Wakefield Town Hall (tall). The spire of Wakefield Cathedral on the right.

images.title: SMJ / Georgian House
images.caption: Georgian House. This lovely Georgian house overlooks the formal gardens in Thornes Park.

images.title: Mike Kirby / Fountain
images.caption: The ornamental fountain in the rose garden normally sends gentle jets of water a few feet into the air.

description: This Yorkshire town is a great base for walkers with numerous local parks, canalside trails, several nearby reservoirs and riverside paths along the Calder. This walk explores Clarence Park, Holmfield Park and Thornes Park in the town centre. The three parks are all located on the south western side of the town and run alongside each other. In the parks you'll find easy surfaced footpaths taking you to rose gardens, a conservatory, a lake and an aviary. After exploring the parks you could head a short distance south to visit the canalside walk at Horbury and the lovely Pugneys Country Park where there's two large lakes and a nature reserve. Please scroll down for the full list of walks near and around Wakefield. The detailed maps below also show a range of footpaths, bridleways and cycle paths in the area.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Holmefield Arms is located in Holmefield Park. It's a fine place for some post walk refreshments with outdoor seating overlooking the park. You can find them at Denby Dale Rd, WF2 8DY.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The parks are a fine place for a dog walk so you're bound to see other owners on your visit. The Holmefield Arms mentioned above is also dog friendly.

display_address: Clarence Park Band Stand, Denby Dale Road, Thornes, Wakefield, West Yorkshire, England, WF2 8DJ, United Kingdom
